tn.text: The word "Sin" here is the Hebrew name of the wilderness. It is not the English word "sin." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_transliterate]])

This is the first month of the Hebrew calendar. It marks when God rescued the Israelites from the Egyptians. The first month is during the last part of March and the first part of April on the Western calendar. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_hebrewmonths]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "and they buried her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "they" refers to the community.
"came as a mob"
This represents being in front of Yahweh's tent. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The people of Israel continue to complain to Moses and Aaron.

tn.ref: Why have you brought Yahweh's community into this wilderness to die here, we and our animals?
tn.text: The people use this question in order to complain against Moses and Aaron. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should not have brought Yahweh's community into this wilderness to die here, we and our animals." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Why did you make us come up out of Egypt to bring us to this horrible place?
tn.text: The people use this question in order to complain against Moses and Aaron. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should not have made us leave Egypt to bring us to this horrible place." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This indicates that Moses and Aaron are humbling themselves before God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
Here "their eyes" represents the people seeing what Moses does.   AT: "while they watch you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This represents Yahweh's tent. AT: "from Yahweh's tent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Must we bring water out of this rock for you?
tn.text: Moses asks this question out of frustration to rebuke the people for complaining. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "You complain that there is no water. Well, we will make water come out of this rock." or "You would not be happy even if we caused water to come out of this rock. But I will do it anyway." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "we" refers to Moses and Aaron and may include Yahweh, but does not include the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: Because you did not trust me or honor me as holy in the eyes of the people of Israel
tn.text: How Moses showed that he did not trust and honor God can be stated clearly. AT: "Because you did not trust me or honor me as holy in the eyes of the people of Israel, but struck the rock instead of speaking to it as I told you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: in the eyes of the people of Israel
tn.text: Here the eyes represents the people seeing what Moses did.  AT: "while the people of Israel were watching you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "People called this place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Moses uses this phrase to emphasize that the Israelites and the Edomites are related because their ancestors, Jacob and Esau, were brothers.

tn.ref: When we called out to Yahweh
tn.text: "When we prayed to Yahweh begging him to help us"
Here "voice" represents their crying or what they said to him. AT:  "he heard our cry" or "he heard what we asked for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Look" here marks a change in topic. They were just speaking about their past. Now they speak about their present situation as they prepare to ask the king to do something.
The messengers continue speaking to the king of Edom.

tn.ref: We will not turn aside to the right hand or to the left
tn.text: Here "turn aside"  represents leaving the road. AT: "We will not leave the road in any direction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the main road that connects Damascus in the north to the Gulf of Aqabah in the south.

tn.ref: You may not pass ... to attack you
tn.text: Here "you" is singular and refers to Moses, who represents the people of Israel. AT: "Your people may not pass ... to attack them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will come with the sword
tn.text: Here the sword represents the king's army. AT: "I will send my army" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This phrase refers to the Israelite messengers.
This idiom means that they would simply travel through the area by walking. They would not come in chariots to attack the people of Edom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: the king of Edom came against Israel with a strong hand with many soldiers
tn.text: Here the hand represents the king's powerful army. AT: "the king of Edom sent a strong army of many soldiers to attack Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "their" refers to the Edomites.

tn.ref: The people of Israel, the whole community
tn.text: The phrase "the whole community" emphasizes that every person who was a part of "the people of Israel" was present, without exception. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: Aaron must be gathered to his people
tn.text: This is a gentle way to say that Aaron must die. It means that it is time for Aaron to die and for his spirit to go to the place where his ancestors are.  AT: "Aaron must die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
Here "my word" represents what God said. AT: "refused to do what I said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
God continues speaking to Moses.

tn.ref: must die and be gathered to his people
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. They mean that it is time for Aaron to die and for his spirit to go to the place where his ancestors are. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"30 days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
